Closed issue "how to make a custom directive that can use inline handlers" (#6753) at vuejs/vue
Events.RelatedBody:
### What problem does this feature solve?
I'd like to make a directive like this
````
<button v-my-custom-directive:say=say('hi)>Say hi</button>
````
It is same like this 
````
<button v-on:click="say('hi')">Say hi</button>
````

how can I make the v-my-custom-directive can run say('hi')
In Vue 2.0  the v-my-custom-directive only can get a result of the say('hi) function

### What does the proposed API look like?
For this below
````
<button v-my-custom-directive:say=say('hi)>Say hi</button>
````
Vue Directive should support an inlineHandler function in the binding
````
Vue.directive('my-custom-directive', {
  bind(el, binding, vNode){
     const {inlineHandler} = binding
     inlineHandler() //  vue directive can run  inline handler like this. this will run say('hi')
  }
}
````

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add a new history mode to allow parallel <router-view> components to work independently" (#1788) at vuejs/vue-router
Events.RelatedBody:
### What problem does this feature solve? The problem occurs when building applications/tools inside of which you need to let your users reorganize their workspace. Users with different needs will configure their workspace to only show what they care about. Let's say I have an application made of 4 different modules: - Module A - Module B - Module C - Module D A user interested in modules A, B and C might configure his workspace like this: ``` ----------------------- ------------ | Module A | Module B | | | | | | | | ------------ | | Module C | | | | | | | | | | | | | ----------------------- ------------ ``` Another user, interested in modules A, B and D will configure his workspace differently: ``` ----------------------- ------------ | Module D | Module B | | | | | | | | ------------ | | Module A | | | | | | | | | | | | | ----------------------- ------------ ``` Here the three sections of the page are independent. They all have their own navigation stack, their own "Back" button. This means that to be able to use a `` in each section to switch between modules, we would need a history mode completely decoupled from the URL of the page. This is very different from named views, it's about allowing multiple virtual navigation roots per application instead of a single one (the URL). The "virtual" history mode would keep track of the parallel navigation branches internally instead of modifying the URL. ### What does the proposed API look like? Using the "virtual" history mode would simply require the user to set `mode` to `'virtual'` inside of the router. ```js const router = new VueRouter({ mode: 'virtual', route: [ // Define routes { path: '/module-a', name: 'a', component: ModuleA }, { path: '/module-b', name: 'b', component: ModuleB }, ... ] }) ``` In templates, parallel `` components will now work independently on their own virtual navigation branch instead of being tied to the URL of the page. Setting the root of a `` component could then be done using either a `string` or a `Location` object, just like the `to` prop on the `` component. ```html
... ```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "router.match(location) not return query object from url like this.$route" (#1786) at vuejs/vue-router
Events.RelatedBody:
### Version
2.7.0

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/BlackCode7/vue-router-bug](https://github.com/BlackCode7/vue-router-bug)

### Steps to reproduce
1. git clone https://github.com/BlackCode7/vue-router-bug
2. npm install
3. npm run dev
4. open console
5. click on the "Get console.log" button
6. Look at both objects, they should be the same but "router.match(location)" loses query parameters

### What is expected?
Objects returned by "this.$route" and "router.match(location)" should be the same

### What is actually happening?
The object returned by "router.match(location)", contains an empty query object inside when there are query in the url

---
Documentation: https://router.vuejs.org/en/api/route-object.html

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Client dom not matching server in SSR" (#978) at vuejs/vuex
Events.RelatedBody:
### Version 2.4.1 ### Reproduction link [https://github.com/amritk/vuex-ssr-issue](https://github.com/amritk/vuex-ssr-issue) ### Steps to reproduce - Set the vuex state in a child component - Use a v-if based on that same state value in the parent component, ie for a title ### What is expected? It should read the value and show/hide the component based on the value, just like in the client. ### What is actually happening? The server side rendered part does not render the component from v-if, the client does, so it shows the error: ``` [Vue warn]: The client-side rendered virtual DOM tree is not matching server-rendered content. This is likely caused by incorrect HTML markup, for example nesting block-level elements inside

, or missing . Bailing hydration and performing full client-side render. ``` --- Now is it because the value is set too late in the child before it is read? Then what would be the correct way to set the title of the parent component from the child routes. *I used the vuetify template since it comes with SSR on the ready, Vuetify does not affect this bug.
